C07B158631724DA2BF7817C9A244701E.description:
Examine how various cultures past and present, including
First Nations and Métis, collect, represent, and use first-hand
data.

0601425BB8B5471BB8128704CD411D1C.description:
Analyze interpretations of bar graphs or line plots and explain
whether or not the interpretation is valid based on the data
display.

C993FBB694B547E99BA80722423A7C67.description:
Pose and solve situational questions related to self, family, or
community by collecting and organizing data, representing
the data using a bar graph or line plot, and interpreting the
data display.

BA2DF03E567947A48BDF672A4CD7A133.description: Collect and represent data using bar graphs or line plots.

8AE0AFA9B0EC4ED6971E05729C1EC74C.description:
Answer questions related to the data presented in a bar
graph or line plots.

93D0C6FA4C244D8FB96A9E1910BA25E4.description:
Analyze a set of bar graphs to determine the common
attributes of bar graphs.

2D478928F487461EA6ED1DABA68BCD54.description: Create a line plot from a pictograph.

217BEED185564098922502264D3BB282.description:
Analyze a set of line plots to determine the common
attributes of line plots.

BD3FE038CA524D5E973D8B0EA06C539D.description:
Observe and describe situations relevant to self, family, or
community in which a particular type of data recording or
organizing strategy might be used, including tally marks,
charts, lists, and knots on a sash.

4A90D67210784AE09CE1926F44BC3426.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of first-hand
data using tally marks, charts,
lists, bar graphs, and line
plots (abstract pictographs),
through:
• collecting, organizing, and
representing
• solving situational
questions.
[C, CN, PS, R, V]

8BA835359EE24D81ABB88C76479EFDDD.description:
Analyze irregular and regular polygons in different orientations
in terms of the characteristics of the polygons (such as number
or measurement of sides and angles).

DBA04BB30CFB491DADDC7AF60CC4855C.description:
Observe, describe the characteristics of, and sort polygons
found in situations relevant to self, family, or community
(including First Nations and Métis), into irregular and regular
polygons (e.g., the bottom of a kamatiq, the screen of a TV, the
bottom of a curling broom, and an arrowhead).

96957F0C772C46F090A80AF7B9664FD9.description:
Generalize definitions for regular and irregular polygons based
on a concept attainment activity or from pre-sorted sets.

3839378C60E448009954777D78624CC1.description: Identify the sorting rule used on a pre-sorted set of polygons.

DAA9EE1B3705415D9E24275DF40FD7D2.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of 2-D shapes
(regular and irregular)
including triangles,
quadrilaterals, pentagons,
hexagons, and octagons
including:
• describing
• comparing
• sorting.
[C, CN, R]

44FE71FD18E24C2FA7BDC7FFE45E851F.description:
Sort a set of 3-D objects according to the faces, edges, or
vertices and explain the sorting rule used.

D0E8DDDBBCD641B78062C428199BFD1C.description: Critique the statement “a vertex is where three faces meet”.

BE8CB294E5CB4494A092338701B5B360.description:
Determine the number of faces, edges, and vertices of a given
3-D object and explain the reasoning and strategies.

D8A128900E7A40C2BCA9B56ED331E998.description:
Construct a skeleton of a given 3-D object and describe how
the skeleton relates to the 3-D object.

34BB35C993494BB8B3A4D9AFDC08AFF0.description: Observe and describe the 2-D shapes found on a 3-D object.

5D2AEAFEE82E45D7A8B69FB3B7C8E11D.description:
Critique the statement “the face of a 3-D object is always a
2-D shape”.

E4733F8D483D461BBE25CC5855CCB525.description:
Observe and describe the faces, edges, and vertices of given
3-D objects, including cubes, spheres, cones, cylinders,
pyramids, and prisms (e.g., drum, tipi, South American
Pyramids, and other objects from the natural environment).

8C6789346DD944E6902D4367359E8DCE.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of 3-D objects
by analyzing characteristics
including faces, edges, and
vertices.
[C, V]

9310BBD7045E456D8A15E1C3C6B8C3A5.description: Sort a set of 2-D shapes into groups with equal perimeters.

F2B72C7BC65548CF9C0A66E6F7D0D4B6.description: Critique the statement “perimeter is a linear measurement”.

17037126B0F749BCB5D3BC57907FB8CD.description:
Estimate the perimeter of a given 2-D shape (cm, m) using
personal referents and explain the strategies used.

005E1A665AA64C529AA2C172D6D9BE9F.description:
Construct or draw more than one 2-D shape for the same
given perimeter (cm, m).

F26F85C5D5B144B89ACDA7925DB8C403.description:
Measure and record the perimeter of a given irregular 2-D
shape, and explain the strategy used.

8668AA467475490C81137B0948A1AEF6.description:
Measure and record the perimeter of regular 2-D polygons
and circles located on 3-D objects, and explain the strategy
used.

A4F98E99E4C04B4F9ECF4D834D218307.description:
Create a picture of a 2-D shape with specified length and
width (or length and height) and explain whether the 2-D
shape was constructed using estimates or actual lengths.

2E22211AE31E4EB791539CDCE06032DC.description:
Relate measuring using a referent for 10 cm to skip counting
quantities by 10s.

AF8E014BC8EA41D6BA043C17A8B82C14.description:
Draw a line segment of a given length and explain the
process used.

E376B3BB452D48AD8F6A93A5F56E8BAE.description:
Sketch a line segment of an estimated length and describe
the strategy used.

CA955FA467CE46AE8EE1147E5D972F9B.description:
Explain why sometimes different names are used for different
length measurements (e.g., height, width, or depth).

A149144AAB854A129B70CCD8C21F40B9.description:
Identify and determine the length of the dimensions of a
personally relevant 2-D shape or 3-D object.

200AF27FF7134CCEA62FADBE92925C04.description:
Pose and solve situational questions that involve the
estimating or measuring of length (including perimeter)
using cm or m.

72851854BF57414296976154B7F6576C.description:
Create models to generalize a numerical relationship
between cm and m (i.e., 100 cm is equivalent to 1 metre).

8D58B99B84CA43C4913A449BE3D50CEA.description:
Measure and compare different lengths on 3-D objects to
select personally relevant referents for 1 cm, 10 cm, and 1 m.

13F56009DC004BD2A6A626712141F4D5.description:
Observe and describe situations relevant to self, family,
and community that involve measuring lengths, including
perimeter, in cm or m.

927A327638444F61892B699F8A6A27F7.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of linear
measurement (cm and m)
including:
• selecting and justifying
referents
• generalizing the
relationship between cm
and m
• estimating length and
perimeter using referents
• measuring and recording
length, width, height, and
perimeter.
[C, CN, ME, PS, R, V]

8025B57C608349DD9E59AB856A082024.description:
Observe and document conversations, mass media reports,
and other forms of text that use the term “weight” rather than
“mass”.

CF145680EDB942A3854E3C5CD268A930.description:
Generalize statements about the mass of a specific amount
of matter when reformed into different shapes or sizes (e.g,
use clay to make an object, measure the mass of the object,
reform the clay into another object and measure the mass
of the two objects; an empty balloon versus a full balloon; or
water versus ice).

6F3A10A698DC4320BF3F9AB951E844BE.description:
Directly compare the mass of two 3-D objects and then verify
the comparison by measuring the actual masses using a scale.

BD053B8DD22E471D85708DF8A49E3EF3.description:
Estimate the mass of an object relevant to one’s self, family, or
community and explain the strategy used.

3C9FDEA98C23434F943D8733137DC473.description:
Determine, using a scale, and record the mass of an object
relevant to one’s self, family, or community.

CE532261281E400E83FAD7AD0EA5987F.description:
Select, with justification, an appropriate unit for measuring
the mass of a given 3-D objects (e.g., kg would be used to
measure a motorbike).

0B77B55C7737491189045DB43A089658.description:
Analyze the relationships between 1 g, 10 g, 100 g, 1000 g,
and 1 kg and explain the strategies used (e.g., 1 kg is heavier
than 100 g, 10 g, and 1 g, or 1 kg is the same mass as 1000 g.)

92B99802B8E94ECF894B70F03EB50DC8.description:
Analyze 3-D objects to determine personal referents for 1 kg,
100 g, 10 g, and 1 g.

254D2D6FC053460183DE48CE0721E284.description:
Create and solve situational questions that involve the
estimating or measuring of mass using g or kg.

90BB728A0D9A4D56B06D7789925A23E1.description:
Observe and describe situations relevant to self, family, and
community that involve measuring mass.

92ED108C63A94725911467DBF04D9D3D.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of measuring
mass in g and kg by:
• selecting and justifying
referents for g and kg
• modelling and describing
the relationship between g
and kg
• estimating mass using
referents
• measuring and recording
mass.
[C, CN, ME, R]

1E8B81429A1546589CB3BCDE12BBB742.description: Describe ways in which the measurement of time is cyclical.

3DAC856619464E7A82C645E5C1339AE2.description:
Create a calendar using the days of the week, the calendar
dates, and personally relevant events.

7C784DE391EA4047AEE3AD25CFCC5E1F.description:
Identify errors in the ordering of the days of the week and the
months of the year.

B5202326AC23456794668DB4A2E61988.description:
Locate a stated or written date (day, month, and year) on a
calendar and explain the strategy used.

DA650CD3E45A41408C3CFF2A9E107C00.description:
Identify today’s date, and then explain how to determine
yesterday’s and tomorrow’s date.

7274A244D8AE4C799AE24F1559224352.description:
Identify the day of the week, the month, and the year for an
indicated date on a calendar.

11CFF24BE3F346DD8086CBC338592CED.description:
Create and solve situational questions using the relationship
between the number of minutes in an hour, days in a
particular month, days in a week, hours in a day, weeks in a
year, or months in a year (e.g., “A student was on holiday for
10 days. Is that more or less than one week long?”).

044F5A7DE0C34DF7B57E3CFB5BC5FD9B.description: Select and justify personal referents for minutes and hours.

DECA4CC7BE8F45FDB148F79D5208B430.description:
Suggest and sort activities into those that can or cannot be
accomplished in a minute, hour, day, month, or year.

828157594EB442958B3074FA33C73C5A.description:
Select and use a personally relevant non-standard unit of
measure for the passage of time (such as television shows, a
pendulum swing, sunrise, sundown, moon cycles, and hunger
patterns) and explain the choice.

032758B0853A45649315DE43FAC82985.description:
Explore the meaning and use of time-keeping language from
different cultures, including First Nations and Métis.

491F97BEE65040199B62281987785A5B.description:
Observe and describe activities relevant to self, family, and
community that would involve the measurement of time.

B95BD95CDEAC45969073CB450A76AAA6.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of the passage
of time including:
• relating common activities
to standard and nonstandard units
• describing relationships
between units
• solving situational
questions.
[C, CN, PS, R]

5ECB6DE0A85F454893B87AEAE731A7EF.description:
Create and solve situational questions that relate to given
one-step equations.

5E3E4A990CA942509E9BD822C64ED28F.description:
Create and solve one-step equations related to situational
questions.

4A8FB10D95AE412B8A53B21B92D125BE.description:
Explain why the unknown in a given addition or subtraction
equation has only one value.

01BDDFDB7D01426B8E5E7DFDA3097BE6.description:
Generalize strategies, including guess and test, for solving
one-step addition and subtraction equations and verify the
strategies concretely, pictorially, or physically.

852B7CF278214811843D134BAD95162E.description:
Verify (concretely, pictorially, or physically) which of a set
of given quantities is the solution to a one-step addition or
subtraction equation and explain the reasoning.

7FE9D7920DE7480B88FF15847559ADBC.description:
Solve addition and subtraction equations concretely,
pictorially, or physically.

1E307CD22D4F49888A2A8AC29D098A15.description:
Compare two equations involving the same operations and
quantities, but using different symbols.

D78F8CF02F3A4495BD6E1556A43CEDA1.description:
Explain the purpose of the symbol, such as a triangle or a
circle, in an addition or subtraction equation.

63477C4ABCE3405183DC322DF3A91760.description:
Observe and describe situations relevant to self, family, or
community in which a symbol could be used to represent an
unknown quantity.

642251172F374F4993D9E06BDD6D16AE.description:
Share, compare, and distinguish between understandings
and uses of the word equal, including those represented in
First Nations and Métis worldviews.

2A1E6EA0DE13478FA7BB7195E83B20EE.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of equality
by solving one-step addition
and subtraction equations
involving symbols representing
an unknown quantity.
[C, CN, ME, R]

F2E9B653770F43D89CBCCFA04654E02E.description:
Research (e.g., through Elders, traditional knowledge
keepers, naturalists, and media) and present about the role
and significance of increasing and decreasing patterns (e.g.,
making of a star blanket, beading, music, and patterns found
in nature) in First Nations and Métis practices, lifestyles, and
worldviews.

B4B17C0760B34E338C916E5A85D261E3.description:
Describe strategies used to solve situational questions
involving increasing or decreasing patterns, including
determining missing elements within the pattern.

552AAA65CCEB4D09AB878073C2170D5C.description:
Create a concrete, physical, pictorial, or symbolic pattern
(increasing or decreasing) and describe the pattern rule.

51EB4CB7EA094292A19C534A1AC740FA.description:
Visualize and create oral, concrete, physical, pictorial, or
symbolic representations for a given increasing or decreasing
pattern rule and explain how the representations are related.

B2F4BFDC6AD24F91A5FCE68E240F46E6.description:
Compare visual patterns for skip counting (forwards or
backwards) by 2s, 5s, 10s, 25s, and 100s and relate to
increasing and decreasing patterns.

FF21267D79304DFFB8D78F48AF431173.description:
Observe various patterns (increasing or decreasing) found
on a hundred chart, such as horizontal, vertical, and diagonal
patterns, and describe the pattern rule.

40877C86C63743888F09CD0372F260B1.description:
Verify (concretely, visually, orally, pictorially, or physically)
whether or not a given sequence of numbers represents an
increasing or decreasing pattern.

44E2C951786343778420C3D53041A0E5.description:
Identify and observe situations relevant to self, family, and
community that contain an increasing or decreasing pattern,
identify the starting value of the pattern, and describe the
rule for the pattern and how the pattern would continue.

1053C3CBE97B4A4283C47777333280E8.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of increasing
and decreasing patterns
including:
• observing and describing
• extending
• comparing
• creating patterns using
manipulatives, pictures,
sounds, and actions.
[C, CN, PS, R, V]

D0014D38E074421D9ADCB792891C4DF9.description:
Explain how a region can be divided into unequal parts, but
the parts still represent a fraction of the region (e.g., Canada
divided into provinces and territories which are not equal in
area).

8E15B6DD365045668DD6E6BA7C5CA722.description:
Represent a fraction as part of a whole, group, region, or
length and explain the representation.

F7DEC43DEF4B4609A4CE2AF9568A20B4.description:
Compare, concretely, pictorially, physically, or orally, and
order a set of fractions with either equivalent denominators
or equivalent numerators.

668B40FE3A404848B11D6800CCC79A20.description:
Demonstrate how a fraction can represent a different amount
if a different size of whole, group, region, or length is used.

AE607C28EFD84D448796B2E669590340.description:
Explain the role of the numerator and denominator in a
fraction.

B3D1F40752F9415886F77E428F15D327.description:
Analyze representations of a set of fractions of a whole,
group, region, or length that all have the same denominator
(e.g., 0/5, 1/5, 2/5, 3/5, 4/5, 5/5) and explain what about the
fractional quantities is similar and what is different.

8D470B495D324B29930D982925CAB728.description:
Analyze representations of a set of fractions of a whole,
group, region, or length that all have the same numerator
(e.g., 2/3, 2/4, 2/5) and explain what about the fractional
quantities is similar and what is different.

2FBEC0E2ADED43F785C82FB1507CD94F.description:
Analyze a set of diagrams or concrete representations to
sort the representations into those that represent the same
fraction and those that do not, and explain the sorting.

AB6E0E6BFF8942359D6403DEC3E18D6A.description:
Divide a whole, group, region, or length into equal parts
(concretely, physically, or pictorially), demonstrate that
the parts are equal in quantity, and name the quantity
represented by each part.

9BB9A1674B1B4318B36A867D02917F37.description:
Explain the relationship of a representation of a fraction to
both a quantity of zero and a quantity of one (the whole or
entire group, region, or length).

316B9134D2C04837A30A36363AE2040F.description:
Explore First Nations and Métis methods of observing and
representing fractional quantities (e.g., consider the concept
of sharing from a First Nations or Métis holistic worldview).

891835388AE84E6E9567B26FD8F0A339.description:
Identify and observe situations relevant to self, family, or
community in which fractional quantities would be measured
or used and explain what the fraction quantifies.

28742500F021426BAC6593FCA9C5AFBB.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of fractions
concretely, pictorially,
physically, and orally including:
• representing
• observing and describing
situations
• comparing
• relating to quantity.
[C, CN, R]

E26EC3D9C5B84CABA9992936A80C3AEB.description:
Create and solve a situational question that relates to a given
symbolic multiplication or division statement.

C38278F7216F430E9CCBB410408DBEBA.description:
Create multiplication or division statements and determine
the resulting products or quotients related to a given
situational question.

B3CD0669A67D4E9A96A8A1E3A8117B80.description:
Relate multiplication and division orally and by using
concrete, physical, or pictorial models, including repeated
addition/subtraction and arrays/dimensions.

0881A34F1B6841F1ADD77F7EF5B4AC6C.description:
Represent and solve an orally presented situational question
that involves division.

3B4132C1776E49B5A5520C30EAF09E8E.description:
Model the commutative property of multiplication and write
the symbolic multiplication equation represented.

2E1FDCBCFBED431D892BF5463DBB3AC3.description:
Apply and explain personal strategies for determining
products and quotients.

E676A033A4A843E2983266234FE39AF8.description:
Represent and solve an orally presented multiplication or
division statement, concretely, physically, or pictorially, using
equal groupings, an array, repeated addition, or repeated
subtraction (e.g., 3 x 4 shown using equal groupings of
snowballs).

CA21A1EC7F5F4048A4166FEF7A8D9B50.description:
Explain and represent concretely, pictorially, orally, or
physically, as well as symbolically, the relationship between
repeated addition and multiplication and the relationship
between repeated subtraction and division.

0D3078C5DBFE4E049651E38D25A61AC8.description:
Observe and describe situations relevant to self, family, or
community that can be represented by equal sharing or
grouping and write and solve a division statement for each
situation.

8CE1A7BB115B4BEBB26FF78F4940A66B.description:
Observe and describe situations relevant to self, family, or
community that can be represented by multiplication and
write and solve a multiplication statement for each situation.

97DED73AE6BE4FE385EBF13B47642E73.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of
multiplication to 5 x 5 and
the corresponding division
statements including:
• representing and
explaining using repeated
addition or subtraction,
equal grouping, and
arrays
• creating and solving
situational questions
• modelling processes using
concrete, physical, and
visual representations,
and recording the process
symbolically
• relating multiplication and
division.
[C, CN, PS, R]

3BBBA3A94FB8481FBA02BC1A94292E59.description:
Provide examples to show why knowing about place value is
useful when adding and subtracting quantities.

D9AA738F41D34D2495D42DB81F1478A9.description: Generalize rules for the addition and subtraction of zero.

2749E37E17D3414288E3B93EC8BE23D6.description:
Transfer knowledge of the basic addition facts up to 18 and
the related subtraction facts to determine the sums and
differences of quantities less than 1000.

84CA8013648B4B72B90068BCC22E9B30.description:
Extend personal mental mathematics strategies to determine
sums and differences (of quantities less than 1000) and
explain the reasoning used.

7A1A750A81F44E188EC504CABB1049B4.description:
Generalize (orally, in writing, concretely, or pictorially)
personal strategies for estimating the sum or difference of
two 2-digit quantities.

904795DC2BFE46F9AA23B54A17574498.description:
Model (concretely or pictorially) a process for the subtraction
of two or more quantities (less than 1000) and record the
process symbolically.

7785A0B123E74832B4A9EC044D72F7B5.description:
Model (concretely or pictorially) a process for the addition of
two or more given quantities (with a sum less than 1000) and
record the process symbolically.

C88E3D4E9A884DF9AF1022DBBFB63994.description:
Create a situational question that involves either addition or
subtraction and that has a given quantity as the solution.

AC8F24E7A94E42AC91E95EA50A5AC1FE.description:
Apply and explain personal mental mathematics strategies to
determine the sums and differences of two-digit quantities.

AE074704AC2F4979A8D34287CB92FEB4.description:
Using doubles (e.g., for 25 - 12, think 12 + 12 = 24 and 24 is
one less than 25, so difference is 12 + 1).

3E3BDCC126FA422E961AD64E1850CB1E.description:
Thinking of addition (e.g., 62 – 45, think 45 + 5, 50 + 12 to
get from 45 to 62, so the difference is 5 + 12)

B0257A15DEB3468F8140C54698B0F3DE.description:
Taking the subtrahends to the nearest multiple or 10 (e.g.,
for 48 - 19, think 48 – 20 + 1)

7766D8CAA0184E3CB2440E1D60A79823.description:
Observe and generalize personal strategies for subtracting
2-digit quantities (given concrete materials, pictures, and
symbolic decompositions) such as:

807D42B7749545CBA5E25F2419A11E6C.description:
Using doubles (e.g., for 24 + 26, think 25 + 25, or for 25 +
26, think 25 + 25 + 1).

80EFB4D9011540CA8F7B8B0DDA7DB6D1.description:
Taking one or both addends to the nearest multiple of 5 or
10 (e.g., for 28 + 47, think 30 + 47 - 2, 50 + 28 – 3, or 30 +
50 – 2 – 3)

2F0FBD09EBEE4EE5B096810EB492278E.description:
Adding from left to right (e.g., for 23 + 46 think 20 + 40 and
3 + 6)

AFE2512B01174AA28BCD9C65E0CC52EC.description:
Observe and generalize personal strategies from different
types of representations for adding 2-digit quantities (given
concrete materials, pictures, and symbolic decompositions)
such as:

E0ED6DF864C54BAFB8B34BD1F0EF36C3.description: doubles take away two (e.g., for 6 + 8, think 8 + 8 – 2)

6FC4D11BC7524F8A8379780FD4E57DE8.description: doubles take away one (e.g., for 6 + 7, think 7 + 7 – 1)

79C501FCEE2145E89BBEFF37C7D717E1.description:
Describe personal mental mathematics strategies that could
be used to determine a given basic fact, such as:

6BB5C9A61EFC48BAACBB8931C009A3A7.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of addition of
whole numbers with answers to
1000 and their corresponding
subtractions (limited to 1,
2, and 3-digit numerals)
including:
• representing strategies for
adding and subtracting
concretely, pictorially, and
symbolically
• solving situational
questions involving
addition and subtraction
• estimating using personal
strategies for adding and
subtracting.
[CN, ME, PS, R, V]

1032FE4BB920448CB5DD3FA6E5A61A3C.description:
Provide examples of how different representations of
quantities, including place value, can be used to determine
sums and differences of whole numbers.

C92D0D42403A48A69B88BC7F6558E768.description:
Explain, using concrete materials or pictures, the meaning of
each digit in a given 3-digit numeral with all the same digits.

1B83531FC7D04EE5B2E9864336D2E151.description:
Record, in more than one way, the quantity represented by
proportional (e.g., base ten blocks) or non-proportional (e.g.,
coins) concrete materials.

E91AF850080A4B0580E0853A0BA230ED.description:
Identify missing whole numbers on a section of a number line
or within a hundred chart.

1DA5A120EE734D50BA62E161EB0C74CE.description:
Analyze a sequence of numbers and justify the conclusion of
whether or not the sequence is ordered.

DC9CA8E9DC3E4EA8B1F1847885F73B10.description:
Select and use referents for 10 or 100 to estimate the number
of groups of 10 or 100 in a set of objects.

036E575561B8439FA1C47DF1EBC25D0A.description:
Create as many different 3-digit numerals as possible,
given three non-repeating digits, and sort the numbers in
ascending or descending order.

B71124C8284E4E6B801DAD711F211681.description:
Sort a set of numbers into ascending or descending order
and justify the result (e.g., using hundred charts, a number
line, or by explaining the place value of the digits in the
numbers).

1A6E20B69C294713A319781B01998251.description:
Create different decompositions of the same quantity
(concretely using proportional or non-proportional
materials, physically, orally, or pictorially), explain how the
decompositions represent the same overall amount, and
record the decompositions as symbolic expressions (e.g.,
300 – 44 and 236 + 20 are two possible decompositions that
could be given for 256).

DE6A2C98004B4A24BBD29BAF19A5277A.description:
Write (in numerals for all quantities, and in words if the
quantity is a multiple of 10 and less than 100 or a multiple of
100 and less than 1000) and read aloud statements relevant
to one’s self, family, or community that contain quantities
up to 1000 (e.g., a student might write, “Our town has a
population of 852” and read the numeral as eight hundred
fifty-two).

F5F6E53AE41B405BBAEF27D76C790098.description:
Identify errors (such as the use of commas or the word ‘and’)
made in speech or in the writing of quantities that occur
in conversations (personal), recordings (such as TV, radio,
or podcasts) and written materials (such as the Internet,
billboards, or newspapers).

2BC01BE765B048B895E02522E1B1BB32.description:
Solve situational questions involving the value of coins or
bills and explain the strategies used (such as grouping or skip
counting).

45EA2A40F0234484A4B1C159EDB8C73A.description:
Analyze a proposed skip counting sequence for errors
(including omissions and incorrect values) and explain the
errors made.

1844526F83394F88920071BFAF65ED1F.description:
Explore and present First Nations and Métis methods of
determining and representing whole number quantities
(e.g., in early Cree language, quantity was a holistic concept
addressing sufficiency for a group such as none/nothing, a
little bit/not many, and a lot).

F607B485FE9447748F103837BEA50F3E.description:
Create and explain the reasoning for a sequence of numbers
that have different skip counting patterns in it (e.g., 3, 6, 9, 12,
16, 20, 24).

F21003C3D54F44179D840AC2CF47AF08.description: by 3s, 4s, or 25s using starting points that are multiples of 3, 4, and 25 respectively.

7B353F5A73AB4AC79D38AADCF57C4025.description: by 5s, 10s, or 100s using any starting point

B8DFB29AFF694E2984A3F4776316B8C6.description:
Analyze a sequence of numbers to identify the skip counting
pattern (forwards or backwards) including:

E5516CC08229467C95CB0085E2FE15A2.description: by 3s, 4s, or 25s using starting points that are multiples of 3, 4, and 25 respectively.

40E8C5CB7F4A42CFB83B5A7A791D6A65.description: by 5s, 10s, or 100s using any starting point

81B30D11FBBC47A194DEB25B78263BE6.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of whole
numbers to 1000 (concretely,
pictorially, physically, orally,
in writing, and symbolically)
including:
• representing (including
place value)
• describing
• estimating with referents
• comparing two numbers
• ordering three or more
numbers.
[C, R, V]
